review_title: Great People, Good Experience, Low Pay
pros: Smart, supportive colleagues and PI's. May not be the case for everyone though. Incredibly grateful to have a thoughtful and brilliant boss with many interesting and hardworking individuals around me.
cons: Pay compared to private industry is getting out of hand. 67% lower in some cases for an equivalent position. Leads to less people being attracted to come here, which was already hard enough because of Baltimore's reputation for safety. This means very few applicants are applying, and managers are forced to pick from of pool of the first and only ~3 people to apply. With passion, good training, and effort on both sides, this can work out fine. However, this is not always the case. I predict a spiral that will only be mitigated by the reputation JHU/JHH maintains through the committed people working tirelessly to propel this field forward.

PTO package is slightly above average for full-timers. Most positions in management/administration are hybrid, so decent work-life balance.
cons: Even if you have a Bachelor's degree, you cannot advance unless you pursue a higher degree - you need a Master's degree to get anywhere. Lower starting pay. job_title: Clinical Research Program Manager in Baltimore, MD
pros:
--Employee Benefits (not salary)
--Networking Opportunities
--Educational Opportunities 
--Easier to identify a new job at JHU if you already work here
cons:
--Hard work is not appreciated or compensated.
--Employees are not appropriately recognized and compesated for getting an advanced degree during their employment. (Even when promised at the beginning.)
--There is a 2% cost of living raise for every one instead of a merit increase. Which means that a great employee and an employee that just gets by, walk away with the same reward--an extra 2% of their current salary. Btw, not enough to see a difference in a paycheck. 
--When approaching leadership for a raise, you are instantly told that the grant won't allow for it
--I caught wind from a friend that works in HR, that the School of Medicine does not compensate employees the way the rest of the university does. 
--Once you get to a certain level in research, you are expected to be available 24/7.

review_title: Be a Part of Something Bigger than Yourself
pros: Quality people who in general believe in the mission of the institution - patient care, research discovery, and education. Excellent benefits including medical, dental, vision, decent amount of time off.  It is a teaching institution at the core, but not only for future doctors.  As an administrator I feel that there are unlimited opportunities for me to learn, be mentored and groomed, and to grow within the company.  No one has ever refused to meet with me in a mentorship type of capacity.  Two new clinical towers are going up right now so I think it will be a very exciting time to work at Johns Hopkins Medicine.
cons: It can be a competitive environment just because of the hundreds of Type As working there.  There are very high standards in general - at least in the jobs I have held over the four years I've worked at JHM.  I work much more than an 8 hour day but I don't know how else I could fit it all in and get my work done.  It would be nice to have newer, more modern facilities, but I think the new clinical towers will help this - plus they will be doing major renovations all through the "old" hospital in the next few years.

review_title: Good place to work ... if you can roll with the punches
pros:
Friendly, professional atmosphere in all of the departments and divisions I've worked in and/or with.

Surrounded by people that genuinely care about their part in patient care. 

Benefits package is great.
cons:
Low salary. Compensation is not merit based, but rather follows a system where parity must be kept among those with a similar title. So if a position requires more effort, or has more duties, than a position of the the similar/same title expect the compensation to be close or the same. Work harder/more, make the same as someone who doesn't.

Posted salary ranges are not accurate, they're a carrot on a stick. All salary ranges posted are for any position within that "band" and not specific to the position itself. So someone will end up applying for a position and wondering why they are at the lower end of the salary range. It's because the actual salary range for that position only occupies a fraction of the band you are shown.

Lack of transparency from management; those most involved in a particular aspect of the patient care chain are often the last to know about critical changes to the workflow.

pros: A great place to work if you don't want job growth beyond the position you get when you enter the company. I don't say that lightly. Some people are on cruise mode and you can find less battles to get promoted because they generally hire from outside vs promoting. Casual dress.  Staff below management are highly skilled in their domains so are excellent to learn from. Internal customer base makes work less intense, if that's something you like. Free parking.
cons: Turnover has been VERY high there for years and so many who left received MUCH higher pay and promotions within a year or 2 of leaving from stronger more notable organizations. This is an indicator of what staff already knew, they were capable, contributing but overlooked employees. But opportunities to show growth there can be based on a 'look' and the development of friendships with some of management, vs an employee's skills and experience. Too much outdated technology- cheapest isn't always best. The job descriptions and interviews make the job seem more challenging than they really are. In some cases, the exciting things to do are given to consultants, then you get to fix their mistakes at half of the pay.  The benefits for school are so regimented and taxed that they aren't worth the drama.  For an insurance company the cost of coverage is high and restriction of what doctors you can see is high.

pros:
Johns Hopkins is prestigious, which you definitely realize when you have patients coming from all over the world to receive care. It feels great to be a part of this. While they may have had issues in the past with leaning on their reputation to keep employees, rather than through benefits/pay/work culture/etc., there have been many improvements. It is evident that they are trying to work harder to make their employees happy. We also get bonuses for healthy living, a points-based peer recognition system, and various perks. There are these types of bonuses for both JHH and JHU sides, though I don't know much about JHHS. Usually, moving up the ladder can be easily achieved.

There are also a lot of ways to help the community through Hopkins. United Way, MLK Day of Service, Payroll deductions to the charity of your choosing, the Buy Local Initiative, and more!
cons:
Various departments can differ widely in terms of employee experience, recognition, management style, HR policies, etc. When I began, everyone told me that the job security is extremely good, impossible to get fired, etc; however, this is one of those things that can vary. In my department, management has displayed how it can be very easy to terminate someone, and HR will usually just go along with the manager. 
While there is an increase in attention to employee health and happiness, the work/life balance is still uneven...financial pressures lead to overworked employees.

Leadership offers very little guidance in terms of strategic direction of the organization, and how teams can work cohesively towards set goal. Salaries are also fairly low when compared to similar jobs in the industry.

pros: The name of Hopkins.  The hospital has amazing doctors & nurses.

Management is only for themselves.  You are not represented by your manager. They just don’t want to get involved, but they do want you to work extra long hours without extra compensation.  Parking fees are horrendous when executive leadership pay NO parking fees.  Do as I say not as I do attitude.   They will use you for everything they can get out of you, then toss you aside for someone making less money who won’t complain about the long hours & hard work without competition or recognition.

pros: Staff is friendly, pharmacists are wonderful, helpful and knowledgable for the most part. Direct nursing manager is fair and extremely competent. Lots of opportunities to learn new skills and gain experience infusing new drugs and protocols.
cons: They worked us to death. Everyone was burned out. Consistently short staffed for home infusion RN's. Newest assistant manager is a micro manager which consistently doesn't work when RN's are in the field and used to the autonomy afforded by the position. Self scheduling is touted as a benefit, but is completely non-existent. The only thing I had control of is patients with timed lab draws, however, the scheduler would sandwich other patients 20 miles away back to back with timed visits. Scheduler is not adept with mapping and would give multiple timed visits which were half hour drives from each other in various directions. It was expected for us to see patients for the entirety of our 40 hours per week, and do our paperwork at home.

pros: Enjoyed working with some co-workers and healthcare providers. Great hours, no weekends or holidays
cons: Very corporate, lots of butt kissing, toxic environment at times, a lot of bullying from management, discrimination

pros: It’s a large place and networking is possible.
cons:
Too many!!!!
First off, sexual advancement on female employees and post docs by so called PIs. Not yielding = losing employment. Underpaid certainly. Mouse colonies are not regulated well, one of them at least has no gowning and operates in an unhygienic way. Wonder if IACUC has ever checked out these places. I even wondered if Hopkins bought its ranking by paying out to US news. It is a very micromanaged place with psychological battery. Like someone said, it’s a revolving door and the administration doesn’t realize how abusive the system is towards female students and staff. Don’t know about men, probably they go through this too. I will never recommend applying here. Maybe I shouldn’t generalize, but info I gathered from a lot of people from different departments has been so. My personal experience made me cry several nights wondering if there was an escape. Staff can escape, students can’t. Worst ever place!

They have better benefits and are more concerned about the welfare of their employees.  No longer has the reputation they did but could improve if new managers were brought in. review_title: Mostly good place to postdoc just don't stay too long.
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow  in Baltimore, MD
pros:
The School of Medicine has agreed to the NIH mandates of post-doc salaries across the board so you at least get guaranteed that, unlike some other institutions which can take advantage of foreign post-docs especially.  It's not like working at a national lab but it's decent.   

As a post-doctoral fellow or graduate student you actually have GREAT healthcare.  The director of University Health has implemented a not-for-profit/break-even self-insurance program that I'm a big fan of.  Your healthcare costs are typically covered at 80-100% and your personal monthly premium is covered by your PI*(not necessarily if you're in the school of public health)  Unfortunately, your spouse or family monthly premiums will be $250+ so it's best to have the spouse usually on their own employer's insurance.  But compared to medical health insurance plans at other high level academic institutions, this is still quite a deal.  There's a dedicated UHS clinic just for students and fellows with GOOD doctors and you never pay for any visits there.  Also, Dental insurance and vision care are also reasonably good.  No benefits for prescription glasses/contacts though.

JHU SOM is also great for fostering a lot of collaborative research opportunities that you can seek out on your own or through your PI's connections within the hospital.  People are very nice and just interested in the research, not as competitive as you might find at other institutions.  You get exposure to amazing cutting edge research too.  The hospital gets some of the most if not the most NIH money and there's a reason.
cons:
For post-docs there's no employer matching for the 403b plan so you may as well start up your own IRA.

You can get stuck in a post-doc position for up to 5 years and then you can move on to a research faculty position but some have called this a "glorified post-doc"

The campus is in the middle of a rough area.  There's a reason they are the number one specialists in gun-related wound care.  But campus security does their job, just don't be stupid and walk home at midnight.

pros: Hopkins Offers some of the best facilities and resources, and attracts very intelligent researchers and a lot of funding. However, not much of this money makes its way back to the researchers who spend most of their time in the lab.
cons: Hopkins's salaries are notoriously low for the positions and work done. The excuse is that Baltimore is a relatively inexpensive city, however the city itself is a good reason to steer clear of Hopkins.

Others are great assets the team, but are not given the recognition/responsibility they should. The good ones either move on or leave, and they go faster then the bad ones.

review_title: Not Your Parent's Johns Hopkins - Started with High Expectations... After a Year, Left Disappointed
job_title: Medical Office Assistant in Chevy Chase, MD
pros:
Willing to send employees for additional training upon request and supervisor approval. State-of-the-art technology as they use the Electronic medical records system EPIC Care and everything is accessible and navigating a patient's chart and information was refreshingly easy and efficient (though a 2 week course in Baltimore is required for all new hires and depending on the individual there can be an extended learning curve).

Flexible Schedule – Because of joining a larger group of cardiologists and the cross training on the EMR EPIC there was flexibility to work at other locations and greater availability to receive the needed coverage for when you wanted to take time off. Scheduling patients was also easier as more doctors, in a variety of locations, made same-day and hospital pre/post procedure scheduling easier and more convenient for the patients.
cons:
Pay - Very low for the area and job title/description. I was working for a private Cardiology practice when they were bought by Johns Hopkins Medicine (or Johns Hopkins Community Physicians) and of course needed to reapply for my position, which I completely understand and cooperated with,  however, even after my former employers and doctors fought to get me a higher hourly wage (trying to get me as close as  possible to the wage I had with them) I still received a pay cut of approximately $15,000 per year. This was with them allowing for me to have a higher wage than was usual for my position.

Health Insurance - One would think that since Hopkins is itself in the healthcare business that they would have excellent benefits. This is not the case, however, since their insurance forces you to use only Johns Hopkins physicians and facilities in order to receive your best in-network benefits. This was a problem because Hopkins does not have the large presence in Montgomery County, MD that it does in Baltimore and so finding specialists, lab facilities, and hospitals that would be in-network was a ongoing issue. 

Reputation - Hopkins' reputation across the country and world is very positive and they are known for their ingenuity and talented surgeons and physicians. This is not true for the majority of the DC Metro Area. When patients were told that their cardiologist was being acquired by Johns Hopkins we received mostly negative feedback. The complaints that were the most common were regarding a shift to more impersonal patient interaction (we no longer directly answered the phone and a new answering system/prompt was implemented) and where patients felt like they were rushed in and out of 15 minute appointments with the doctor and only saw him for 5 minutes, with no real face-to-face time as he became concerned with deal with the computer and couldn't look at the patients anymore.

pros: This is an excellent academic center and job opportunity. The environment is highly collaborative. The institution offers a unique opportunity to work and collaborate with individuals, departments, and fields outside one's own. While highly invested in their work, colleagues are exceptionally helpful with promoting academic development of younger trainees who are beginning their career. This is by far one of the premier academic institutions in the country and an exceptional location to trainee and beginning a rich academic career in medicine.
cons: Salary at the lower end of comparative competitive salaries.

pros: Laboratory facilities are second to none.  Pleasant environment for working.  The reputation adds to the exhilaration.  Great experience overall.

review_title: Johns Hopkins Doesn't Love You Back
job_title: Professor of Medicine in Baltimore, MD
pros: Working with highly talented colleagues.  Very little organization or structure.  The management tries to be "Top Down" but does not have resources to provide faculty or staff who work as independent entrepreneurs.
cons: The salary scale is very low compared to comparable medical schools.  The goal of the medical school is to put the mean salary at the 25% of the AAMC, but they are not able to do it.

cons: Hopkins doesn't pay as much as some other institutions, but that is offset by excellent benefits such as tuition assistance and a great work life balance.

review_title: World-class training environment, but can be difficult to advance.

cons: Very challenging to advance within the system.  Extremely competitive (for better or worse) environment that can at times do more to quell innovation than encourage it. Expansionist values sometimes lead to neglect of core research infrastructure.

cons: Some of the least-effective, most-protective, and quintessentially-counterproductive Administrators/bureaucrats on the planet.  Creative people need not apply without receiving assurances that their creativity will be valued.

review_title: Truly the weirdest, most bizarre place I've worked
job_title: Business Process Analyst in Baltimore, MD
pros: Absolutely nothing (but keep in mind that I've worked at some of the best organizations in the nation and coming here was a culture shock. context matters)
cons:
The people were so unfriendly and unwelcoming.  When I was brand new and would introduce myself via email to peers across different departments for help, I would literally never get a response back. No one responds to emails there! 

There was no transparency and communication. The Epic transition was a nightmare and numerous reporting capabilities were just lost, but when I reached out to people to mitigate this I got no responses from them. No one knew what to do or who to contact.

My actual job was a nightmare. They really tried to combine two positions into one very low-paying job and it just didn't work. I worked with managers from two completely different areas, and I constantly had competing priorities. I always got the impression that my managers thought I was slacking off but I was really just working on projects for the other person. Also because people in outside departments wouldn't respond to my emails for assistance (despite multiple follow-ups), it would delay my progress on projects which also made it appear as if I weren't doing anything. 

My managers were awful. They never provided direct feedback and were just extremely passive aggressive. I didn't realize that Hopkins had a four month probation period and I also didn't know that my managers were concerned enough about my performance to extend it because they just didn't tell me. My finance boss was a condescending jerk who talked to me like I was an idiot.

Hopkins doesn't operate like it's one of the best universities in the world. The office that I worked in was run-down and they barely turned the AC on in the summer and didn't turn the heat on in the winter. So cheap. 

Finally Hopkins doesn't treat it's employees well. I gave my notice last week and when I came in to work a couple of days ago, they revoked my access to the shared drive even though I still have a week left in my notice period. I'm sure one of my managers requested this out of spite but I don't understand why they would be so petty and how they expect me to wrap up projects. Oh well, I will be surfing the internet for a week while getting paid. Works for me.

pros: Great environment! Diverse group and plenty of volunteer oppurtunities. Some good benefits as well as flexible working hours.
cons: Low pay. Don't believe the hype. They will have you broke, busted and disgusted in the claims department. Ok, if you live with others or have a roomate. If you're independent and live on your own, it's a good idea to get another job if you accept a position in claims.

review_title: "Johns Hopkins HealthCare: Talks the talk, but doesn't Walk the Walk"
pros: The only positive thing I can say about this company is that it offers employees an excellent benefits package (but this comes at a cost, as the salaries offered are low and decent pay raises are non-existent).
cons:
I have a lot I could say here, but for the sake of time, let me just sum up some major points (based upon my personal experience):

1) JHHC preaches diversity and inclusion constantly, but at the end of the day, they don't seem to actually care about issues when they arise. I have witnessed more than one employee be unjustly terminated from their position, and it was horrible to witness. 
2) Human Resources could care less about employees. They are NOT a group of people an employee can rely upon in difficult times. They will side with the leadership of a department, even if the leadership is clearly causing great pain and frustration to their staff (as has happened in my department). Our concerns and requests always fall upon deaf ears. 
3) Terrible management/leadership and employees are permitted to remain employed, even if they don't produce good work or even care about their jobs. Only hardworking, outspoken and honest employees are at risk to be terminated. The company seems to embrace mediocrity and look down upon those who want to excel. It's bizarre! I'm quite sure that Johns Hopkins himself would be disappointed with how this company is being run and how employees are being treated.

pros: They offers me really good and reliable benefit. People in the same workplace are friendly and nice to each other.
cons: They average salary is relatively low and not as mush as high other same work field. The neighborhood is dangerous to live.

review_title: Great place but you have to stay focussed

review_title: Good place to learn, academic center
pros: Great learning opportunities, people are willing and eager to teach, typical academic center and great place to be if you are a clinician or researcher.
cons:
Poor salaries

Work culture and subculture can differ within specific areas, its a luck of draw, and you can end up with very supportive management or not.

job_title: Web Applications Developer in Hanover, MD
pros:
Cultural Diversity.  It is a stellar place to talk and learn about other people from all walks of life.

Your co-workers are often talented and care about their jobs.

Health Benefits almost off-set the lower salary.
cons:
Hopkins suffers from a very complex issue stemming from a lack of understanding of the capabilities of IT and it's role within the industry.  This creates many situations where improper software is implemented and unable to meet the needs of the company.  

This lack of understanding is made worse by a hierarchy where unqualified individuals enact demands upon the department.  Extraordinary amounts of money are spent and wasted purchasing software and then attempting to force it to complete tasks it was never meant to accomplish.

You would think this would create an exceptional amount of work for programmers but the contracts are poorly handled and the work gets outsourced to companies supplying the inadequate product.

This inability to define and and settle on company needs vs wants is reflected in the management staff.  This creates an entire office of resource and skills-starved senior staff unable to provide direction or care for their employees.  Instead they are forced to spend time justifying their own employment and pass their mistakes to the people below them.  Several managers are so egregiously bad I would recommend outright avoidance of this company.

The I.T. department is in a constant state of fire-fighting thanks to software debt placed upon it.  Management appears to be completely unable to plan beyond 2 weeks in the future and coordination with the lower staff is completely non-existent.  Basic productivity metrics have not been implemented.  

Suffice to say the list of problems is far longer than listed here.

TL;DR - 20 years of technical debt will keep any IT professional from utilizing the present day skills required of them.  Managers will get in your way intentionally more than actually helping you.  There are no resources granted to the department to advance your career.
